questions.title: The Firm and Market Structures
questions.question:
Six companies in an industry have the following market shares:
Company A B C D E F
Market Share (%) 30 25 16 12 10 7

If Companies D and F merge into a new Company, G, the industry’s three-company concentration ratio would be closest to:

  1. 71%.
  2. 72%.
  3. 74%.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. 71% is the concentration ratio of the original top three companies: A (30%) + B (25%) + C (16%). Incorrect. 72% is the concentration ratio of the top three companies if the two smallest merge: A (30%) + B (25%) + [E (10%) + F (7%)]. Correct. The concentration ratio for the top three companies would be 74%: A (30%) + B (25%) + G (12% + 7%). The Firm and Market Structures identify the type of market structure within which a firm operates and describe the use and limitations of concentration measures
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. 71% is the concentration ratio of the original top three companies: A (30%) + B (25%) + C (16%).

  2. Incorrect. 72% is the concentration ratio of the top three companies if the two smallest merge: A (30%) + B (25%) + [E (10%) + F (7%)].

  3. Correct. The concentration ratio for the top three companies would be 74%:

    A (30%) + B (25%) + G (12% + 7%).

questions.title: The Firm and Market Structures
questions.question: The short-term shutdown point of production for a firm operating under perfect competition will most likely occur when:

choices.A: price is equal to average total cost.
choices.B: marginal revenue is equal to marginal cost.
choices.C: marginal revenue is equal to average variable costs.

questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. The firm should shut down production when marginal revenue is less than or equal to average variable cost.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is correct. The firm should shut down production when marginal revenue is less than or equal to average variable cost.

Solution

A is correct. A company is said to break even if its total revenue is equal to its total cost. Under conditions of perfect competition, a company will break even when market price is equal to the minimum point of the average total cost curve.

questions.title: The Firm and Market Structures
questions.question:
Which of the following indicators suggest(s) a monopoly market?

  1. A concentration ratio of 100% only
  2. A Herfindahl–Hirschman index of zero only
  3. Both a concentration ratio of 100% and a Herfindahl–Hirschman index of zero
questions.explanation: Solution Correct because the concentration ratio is the sum of the market shares of the largest N firms. This number is always between zero (perfect competition) and 100 percent (monopoly). Incorrect because O.C. Herfindahl and A.O. Hirschman suggested an index where the market shares of the top N companies are first squared and then added. If one firm controls the whole market (a monopoly), the Herfindahl–Hirschman index (HHI) equals 1. Incorrect because O.C. Herfindahl and A.O. Hirschman suggested an index where the market shares of the top N companies are first squared and then added. If one firm controls the whole market (a monopoly), the Herfindahl–Hirschman index (HHI) equals 1. The Firm and Market Structures identify the type of market structure within which a firm operates and describe the use and limitations of concentration measures
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Correct because the concentration ratio is the sum of the market shares of the largest N firms. This number is always between zero (perfect competition) and 100 percent (monopoly).

  2. Incorrect because O.C. Herfindahl and A.O. Hirschman suggested an index where the market shares of the top N companies are first squared and then added. If one firm controls the whole market (a monopoly), the Herfindahl–Hirschman index (HHI) equals 1.

  3. Incorrect because O.C. Herfindahl and A.O. Hirschman suggested an index where the market shares of the top N companies are first squared and then added. If one firm controls the whole market (a monopoly), the Herfindahl–Hirschman index (HHI) equals 1.

  3. probability of new entry into the market.

Incorrect because just like the concentration ratio, the HHI does not take the possibility of entry into account, nor does it consider the elasticity of demand. Incorrect because just like the concentration ratio, the HHI does not take the possibility of entry into account, nor does it consider the elasticity of demand. questions.title: The Firm and Market Structures
questions.question:
Under which of the following market structures is product differentiation most important?

  1. Monopoly
  2. Perfect competition
  3. Monopolistic competition
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because the least competitive market structure is monopoly. In pure monopoly markets, there are no other good substitutes for the given product or service. There is a single seller, which, if allowed to operate without constraint, exercises considerable power over pricing and output decisions. Incorrect because perfect competition is a reality—for example, in several commodities markets, where sellers and buyers have a strictly homogeneous product and no single producer is large enough to influence market prices. Product differentiation is not possible under perfect competition. Correct because monopolistic competition is also highly competitive; however, it is considered a form of imperfect competition. The competitive characteristic is a notably large number of firms, while the monopoly aspect is the result of product differentiation. That is, if the seller can convince consumers that its product is uniquely different from other, similar products, then the seller can exercise some degree of pricing power over the market. The Firm and Market Structures identify the type of market structure within which a firm operates and describe the use and limitations of concentration measures
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect because the least competitive market structure is monopoly. In pure monopoly markets, there are no other good substitutes for the given product or service. There is a single seller, which, if allowed to operate without constraint, exercises considerable power over pricing and output decisions.

  2. Incorrect because perfect competition is a reality—for example, in several commodities markets, where sellers and buyers have a strictly homogeneous product and no single producer is large enough to influence market prices. Product differentiation is not possible under perfect competition.

  3. Correct because monopolistic competition is also highly competitive; however, it is considered a form of imperfect competition. The competitive characteristic is a notably large number of firms, while the monopoly aspect is the result of product differentiation. That is, if the seller can convince consumers that its product is uniquely different from other, similar products, then the seller can exercise some degree of pricing power over the market.

questions.title: The Firm and Market Structures
questions.question:
A disadvantage of the concentration ratio is that it:

  1. requires a large number of time-series observations.
  2. is largely unaffected by mergers among the top market incumbents.
  3. requires the specification of the explanatory variables used in regression analysis.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because the main advantage of the concentration ratio is that it is simple to compute. Alternative measures such as regression analysis is useful in computing elasticity but requires a large number of observations. Therefore, one may use a time-series approach and, for example, look at 20 years of quarterly sales data for a market. However, the market structure may have changed radically over those 20 years. Correct because a disadvantage of the concentration ratio is that it tends to be unaffected by mergers among the top market incumbents. For example, if the largest and second-largest incumbents merge, the pricing power of the combined entity is likely to be larger than that of the two pre-existing companies. But the concentration ratio may not change much. Incorrect because because the main advantage of the concentration ratio is that it is simple to compute. Further, an alternative approach is a cross-sectional regression analysis. Different specifications of the explanatory variables (for example, using total GDP rather than median household income or per-capita GDP to represent income) may sometimes lead to dramatically different estimates. The Firm and Market Structures identify the type of market structure within which a firm operates and describe the use and limitations of concentration measures
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect because the main advantage of the concentration ratio is that it is simple to compute. Alternative measures such as regression analysis is useful in computing elasticity but requires a large number of observations. Therefore, one may use a time-series approach and, for example, look at 20 years of quarterly sales data for a market. However, the market structure may have changed radically over those 20 years.

  2. Correct because a disadvantage of the concentration ratio is that it tends to be unaffected by mergers among the top market incumbents. For example, if the largest and second-largest incumbents merge, the pricing power of the combined entity is likely to be larger than that of the two pre-existing companies. But the concentration ratio may not change much.

  3. Incorrect because because the main advantage of the concentration ratio is that it is simple to compute. Further, an alternative approach is a cross-sectional regression analysis. Different specifications of the explanatory variables (for example, using total GDP rather than median household income or per-capita GDP to represent income) may sometimes lead to dramatically different estimates.

questions.title: The Firm and Market Structures
questions.question:
Which characteristic is a firm least likely to exhibit if it faces a downward sloping demand curve for its product(s), many competitors, and zero economic profits in the long run?

  1. No pricing power
  2. Low barriers to entry
  3. Differentiated product
questions.explanation: Solution Correct. The characteristics of monopolistic competition include a large number of competitors, low pricing power, and the production of differentiated products (through advertising and other non-price strategies), but these still result in some pricing power. The ease of entry results in zero economic profits in the long run. Incorrect. Low barriers to entry are a characteristic of monopolistic competition. Incorrect. Product differentiation is a characteristic of monopolistic competition. The Firm and Market Structures describe characteristics of perfect competition, monopolistic competition, oligopoly, and pure monopoly
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Correct. The characteristics of monopolistic competition include a large number of competitors, low pricing power, and the production of differentiated products (through advertising and other non-price strategies), but these still result in some pricing power. The ease of entry results in zero economic profits in the long run.

  2. Incorrect. Low barriers to entry are a characteristic of monopolistic competition.

  3. Incorrect. Product differentiation is a characteristic of monopolistic competition.

The Firm and Market Structures

  • describe characteristics of perfect competition, monopolistic competition, oligopoly, and pure monopoly

questions.title: The Firm and Market Structures
questions.question:
Successful advertising and product differentiation are most likely to have a positive impact on the economic profits of a producer under:

  1. monopoly.
  2. perfect competition.
  3. monopolistic competition.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. Under monopoly, advertising and product differentiation are of little consequence in determining economic profits. Incorrect. Under perfect competition, all producers (and all consumers) are price takers, and economic profits do not exist. Correct. Advertising and product differentiation are most likely to have a positive impact on the economic profits of producers under monopolistic competition. The monopoly aspect of this structure arises from the ability to differentiate its product. The Firm and Market Structures describe characteristics of perfect competition, monopolistic competition, oligopoly, and pure monopoly
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. Under monopoly, advertising and product differentiation are of little consequence in determining economic profits.

  2. Incorrect. Under perfect competition, all producers (and all consumers) are price takers, and economic profits do not exist.

  3. Correct. Advertising and product differentiation are most likely to have a positive impact on the economic profits of producers under monopolistic competition. The monopoly aspect of this structure arises from the ability to differentiate its product.

The Firm and Market Structures

  • describe characteristics of perfect competition, monopolistic competition, oligopoly, and pure monopoly

choices.C: it is operating beyond the minimum point on the long-run average total cost curve.

Solution

questions.title: The Firm and Market Structures
questions.question:
A firm in a market environment characterized by monopolistic competition is most likely to:

  1. continue to experience economic profit in the long run.
  2. have a well-defined supply function reflecting its marginal and average costs.
  3. have many competitors each following its own product differentiation strategy.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. Just as with the perfectly competitive market structure, with relatively low entry costs, more firms will enter the market and lure some customers away from the firm making an economic profit. The loss of customers to new entrant firms will drive down the demand for all firms producing similar products. In the long run for the monopolistically competitive firm, economic profit will fall to zero. Incorrect. In monopolistic competition, there is no well-defined supply function. The information used to determine the appropriate level of output is based on the intersection of MC and MR. However, the price that will be charged is based on the market demand schedule. The firm’s supply curve should measure the quantity the firm is willing to supply at various prices. That information is not represented by either marginal cost or average cost. Correct. As the name implies, monopolistic competition is a hybrid market structure. The most distinctive factor in monopolistic competition is product differentiation. Although the market is made up of many firms that compose the product group, each producer attempts to distinguish its product from that of the others, and product differentiation is accomplished in a variety of ways. The Firm and Market Structures describe characteristics of perfect competition, monopolistic competition, oligopoly, and pure monopoly
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. Just as with the perfectly competitive market structure, with relatively low entry costs, more firms will enter the market and lure some customers away from the firm making an economic profit. The loss of customers to new entrant firms will drive down the demand for all firms producing similar products. In the long run for the monopolistically competitive firm, economic profit will fall to zero.

  2. Incorrect. In monopolistic competition, there is no well-defined supply function. The information used to determine the appropriate level of output is based on the intersection of MC and MR. However, the price that will be charged is based on the market demand schedule. The firm’s supply curve should measure the quantity the firm is willing to supply at various prices. That information is not represented by either marginal cost or average cost.

  3. Correct. As the name implies, monopolistic competition is a hybrid market structure. The most distinctive factor in monopolistic competition is product differentiation. Although the market is made up of many firms that compose the product group, each producer attempts to distinguish its product from that of the others, and product differentiation is accomplished in a variety of ways.

The Firm and Market Structures

  • describe characteristics of perfect competition, monopolistic competition, oligopoly, and pure monopoly

Solution

questions.title: The Firm and Market Structures
questions.question:
In long-run equilibrium, the perfectly competitive firm's supply curve is best represented by the firm's long-run:

  1. marginal cost schedule.
  2. average revenue schedule.
  3. marginal revenue schedule.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct because the long-run marginal cost schedule is the perfectly competitive firm’s supply curve. The firm’s demand curve is dictated by the aggregate market’s equilibrium price. The basic rule of profit maximization is that MR = MC, as is the case in long-run equilibrium. Incorrect because the horizontal line that represents the firm’s demand curve is the firm’s AR [average revenue] schedule. Incorrect because in a perfectly competitive market structure the firm’s demand schedule is the same as the firm’s marginal revenue and average revenue. Given its cost of operation, the only decision the perfectly competitive firm faces is how much to produce. The answer is the level of output that maximizes its return, and that level is where MR = MC. The demand curve is perfectly elastic. Of course, the firm constantly tries to find ways to lower its cost in the long run. The Firm and Market Structures explain supply and demand relationships under monopolistic competition, including the optimal price and output for firms as well as pricing strategy
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Correct because the long-run marginal cost schedule is the perfectly competitive firm’s supply curve. The firm’s demand curve is dictated by the aggregate market’s equilibrium price. The basic rule of profit maximization is that MR = MC, as is the case in long-run equilibrium.

  2. Incorrect because the horizontal line that represents the firm’s demand curve is the firm’s AR [average revenue] schedule.

  3. Incorrect because in a perfectly competitive market structure the firm’s demand schedule is the same as the firm’s marginal revenue and average revenue. Given its cost of operation, the only decision the perfectly competitive firm faces is how much to produce. The answer is the level of output that maximizes its return, and that level is where MR = MC. The demand curve is perfectly elastic. Of course, the firm constantly tries to find ways to lower its cost in the long run.

  • explain supply and demand relationships under monopolistic competition, including the optimal price and output for firms as well as pricing strategy

questions.title: The Firm and Market Structures
questions.question:
Under monopolistic competition, a firm's supply curve is represented by:

  1. average cost.
  2. marginal cost.
  3. neither average cost nor marginal cost.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because in perfect competition, the firm’s supply schedule is represented by the marginal cost schedule. In monopolistic competition, there is no well-defined supply function. The information used to determine the appropriate level of output is based on the intersection of MC and MR. However, the price that will be charged is based on the market demand schedule. The firm’s supply curve should measure the quantity the firm is willing to supply at various prices. That information is not represented by either marginal cost or average cost. Incorrect because in perfect competition, the firm’s supply schedule is represented by the marginal cost schedule. questions.title: The Firm and Market Structures
questions.question:
Three firms operate under perfect competition, producing 900 units of the same product but using different production technologies. Each company’s cost structure is indicated in the table:
Company X Y Z
Total Variable Costs $2,700 $3,600 $4,500
Total Fixed Costs 2,700 1,800 900
Total Costs $5,400 $5,400 $5,400

Which of the following statements is most accurate? If the unit selling price is:

  1. $6.00, all firms should exit the market in the long run.
  2. $3.00, Firm X should continue to operate in the short run, but Firms Y and Z should shut down production.
  3. $4.50, all firms should continue to operate in the short run, but exit the market in the long run if these conditions are expected to persist.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. If total revenue equals or exceeds total costs, the firms should remain in the market both in the long and short run: each firm is just earning an economic profit, which includes its opportunity cost. Correct. Revenue–Cost Relationship Short-Run Decision Long-Term Decision TR ≥ TC Stay in market Stay in market TR TVC but TR TFC + TVC Stay in market Exit market TR TVC Shut down production Exit market TR = Total Revenue; TC = Total Costs; TVC = Total Variable Costs; TFC = Total Fixed Costs Hence, if the selling price is $3.00, total revenue for all firms will be $3.00/unit × 900 units = $2,700. Only Firm X’s variable costs are covered and it should continue operating, while Firms Y and Z should immediately shut down production. Incorrect. At $4.50, total revenue is $4.50 × 900 = $4,050. Only Firms X and Y cover their variable costs; Firm Z should shut down. It is true, however, that if conditions persist, all should shut down in the long run as they won’t be covering their total costs. The Firm and Market Structures determine and interpret breakeven and shutdown points of production, as well as how economies and diseconomies of scale affect costs under perfect and imperfect competition
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. If total revenue equals or exceeds total costs, the firms should remain in the market both in the long and short run: each firm is just earning an economic profit, which includes its opportunity cost.

  2. Correct.

    Revenue–Cost Relationship Short-Run Decision Long-Term Decision
    TR ≥ TC Stay in market Stay in market
    TR TVC but TR TFC + TVC Stay in market Exit market
    TR TVC Shut down production Exit market

    TR = Total Revenue; TC = Total Costs; TVC = Total Variable Costs; TFC = Total Fixed Costs

    Hence, if the selling price is $3.00, total revenue for all firms will be $3.00/unit × 900 units = $2,700. Only Firm X’s variable costs are covered and it should continue operating, while Firms Y and Z should immediately shut down production.

  3. Incorrect. At $4.50, total revenue is $4.50 × 900 = $4,050. Only Firms X and Y cover their variable costs; Firm Z should shut down. It is true, however, that if conditions persist, all should shut down in the long run as they won’t be covering their total costs.

questions.title: The Firm and Market Structures
questions.question:
A manufacturing company expanded in a new region by setting up local assembly lines and hiring local staff. Two years later, the company's sale had grown as expected but operating margin had shrunk from 15 to 12 percent. The company:

  1. has yet to reach its breakeven volume.
  2. is suffering from diseconomies of scale.
  3. has reached its minimum efficient scale.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because breakeven is the point where total revenues equal total costs and hence operating profit is zero. The company’s operating margins are positive; therefore, it is operating above breakeven. Correct because the company is most likely suffering from diseconomies of scale. It is having to duplicate all costs in each location, and by targeting different demographics, it has added additional costs for inputs and marketing. Therefore, the company’s fixed costs have increased faster than output, and the economic result is diseconomies of scale. Incorrect because the minimum point on the LRAC curve is referred to as the minimum efficient scale. Since profits are lower than before the expansion, the company is not yet operating at the least-cost point. The Firm and Market Structures determine and interpret breakeven and shutdown points of production, as well as how economies and diseconomies of scale affect costs under perfect and imperfect competition

Solution

  1. Incorrect because breakeven is the point where total revenues equal total costs and hence operating profit is zero. The company’s operating margins are positive; therefore, it is operating above breakeven.

It is having to duplicate all costs in each location, and by targeting different demographics, it has added additional costs for inputs and marketing. Therefore, the company’s fixed costs have increased faster than output, and the economic result is diseconomies of scale.

questions.title: The Firm and Market Structures
questions.question:
Which of the following statements about a downward-sloping long-run average cost (LRAC) curve is most accurate? A downward-sloping LRAC curve is representative of a firm experiencing:

  1. economies of scale.
  2. diseconomies of scale.
  3. decreasing levels of investment.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct. When the LRAC curve is downward sloping, it means the firm is producing units at lower average costs per unit as production levels rise. This situation represents economies of scale in production. Incorrect. An upward-sloping LRAC curve would be representative of diseconomies of scale. Incorrect. Decreasing levels of investment alone would not result in a downward-sloping LRAC curve; it would also depend on the volume of production. If the level of production drops proportionately more than the level of investment, the LRAC curve could be upward sloping. The Firm and Market Structures determine and interpret breakeven and shutdown points of production, as well as how economies and diseconomies of scale affect costs under perfect and imperfect competition

  2. Incorrect. An upward-sloping LRAC curve would be representative of diseconomies of scale.

  3. Incorrect. Decreasing levels of investment alone would not result in a downward-sloping LRAC curve; it would also depend on the volume of production. If the level of production drops proportionately more than the level of investment, the LRAC curve could be upward sloping.
